text: thank you so much for the introduction and hi everyone great to be here thanks so much for having me it's great to

really exciting for me really enjoyed the conversations that i've had so far and the conversations i'll be able to have later
as well so let me go ahead and share my screen here
okay i'm assuming people can see that we're good to go okay oh so so like michael said um the the
title of my talk today and the topic overall is going to be around accessible virtual reality for people
with limited mobility so i'm going to get into that but first i kind of wanted to be able to provide
just a little bit more background about me who i am so uh
starting off a little bit my educational background so before i was at the university of washington i received my bachelor's and master's in
computer science from bowling green state university bowling green is a small college town in
um in ohio um that is close to home i'm from detroit originally so that was
really great for me um and then after that i left and went to washington so i got my phd
in the in information science from the information school at the university of washington in 2018
and then after leaving there i joined first as a postdoc in the ability group at microsoft
research and i'm now currently a senior researcher in a group since the last three or four months or so
and this is just a quick overview of the other people on the ability team some of the people here's research um you're going to hear mentioned this i
talk about the different stuff that we've been working on so there's andy bagel at couture sasha universe
myself and john ton so i want to start off by providing an
overview of what my talk is going to entail today so first anytime i'd like to do any of these presentations i always like to
talk a little bit about accessible computing i think accessibility is something that people might have some
idea around but i don't think it's something that's as core to our hci knowledge as it should be and
i know you've had patrick and other people patrick carrington and other people this um quarter give talk so then there may be
things that you've heard already in this space but i think when it comes to accessibility i don't think you can hear it too many
times so i'll talk a little bit about some how i think about accessible computing and then i'm going to
lead that into kind of how does my thoughts about accessibility or accessible computing how does that inform my research so i'm going to talk
a little bit about my overall research approach and then from there i'm going to talk about this notion of how do we move more
towards accessible vr primarily for people with limited mobility and since this is ongoing work and
things that are in flux and since kind of midway through me working on this work you know we went
through this you know shutdown with the covet pandemic and everything so a lot of the work that i would prefer to do of
like in person co-design type of things we're not able to do you know essentially over the past year or so due to the
stay-at-home orders and the social distancing restrictions and things like that but i'm gonna my plan there is to give
you an overview or at least a little bit of information about some of the interesting problems that we've identified in this space and i would
love to kind of just have a broader conversation about what that might entail for more accessible vr
interactions in the future and then i'm going to end kind of talking about some other opportunities
that exist so some things that are outside my media research area but things that i think would be
really great in fruitful areas of research that people could chat about so that's the overview of the
talk um and i'm not sure how q a or things are going to go exactly but i'm okay if
there is something that i say and you want to interrupt me and ask a question that's usually okay with me so just let
me know but if we want to wait to the end to do questions that works as well so um so first all right i'm going to start
off talking a little bit about accessible computing and kind of how i think about accessible computing so i kind of like to start off with this
definition which is to say that um i really think about accessibility in these kind of two
ways so one is this notion of like well how can we design computing devices and services to be usable by all people
and then the second part of that is you know well how can we use computing to also make the world more accessible to people with disabilities so you can
really look at accessibility in these two different ways and there's been a lot of great work for a lot of years
looking at well how can we think about accessible design and what does that mean to incorporate accessible design into the development
of technology so one really popular method that people have employed to do that is to look at
universal design so i have a definition here from universal design which says that
it's really the design of products and environments that can be used and experienced by people of all ages and abilities
to the greatest extent possible without adaptation and the thing to notice about universal design is that it really comes
out of architecture discipline so it really you could think of it as like well how can we make built environments
more accessible and you know how we can have people be able to experience these things without requiring adaptation and then
when it comes to things you know using universal design to create more accessible technologies it just kind of gives you a lot of great
stuff right so you can think of curb cuts it's like a great example universal design is probably the most canonical example that
people use often so you can make card cuts you can make it easier for people who use wheelchairs or other implements to be
able to you know navigate safely from the sidewalk to the street but then you're gonna also get these carryover benefits
that you know great for people on skateboards a bicycle is a person pushing a stroller et cetera
and the same thing with closed captioning so we can have text that represents audio that's happening on whatever
program we might be watching which is really great because you can make this content more accessible to people
who may be deaf hard of hearing but it's also great if you're like up really late at night trying to get like a baby to sleep but you want to
just put something on the tv and you just turn closed captioning on right or you're in a really crowded restaurant well
in the past life you were a really crowded restaurant and you wanted to watch something on tv you would put the closed captionings on
so so great stuff universal design gives us so but if we go back to this definition
and we interrogate a little bit more it asks this really interesting question so i'm just going to read the definition again so it says the design of products and
environments that can be used and experienced by people of all ages and abilities to the greatest extent possible without adaptation
um so there's this really heavy emphasis that i put in a slide here on abilities because it begs this question like well
what is ability in this case how do we think about ability how do we measurability what do we do with ability
um so one of the ways that's really useful and that's been influential to the way i
think about accessibility research is to incorporate a design approach called
callability based design so ability-based design is a designed approach that was formulated
by jake robrock and colleagues jake was my advisor when i was at the university of washington
and in ability-based design what it does is that it gives computer systems options to understand
what human abilities are required to operate an interactive system and they're questioned and then you want
to understand how systems can adapt or be adapted to these alternative abilities so it really puts the
abilities part first in thinking about how you might want to design different technologies
for people so again still this notion of like okay well what is ability and an example that comes out of this is
well you can really just think of ability as possession of the means or skills to do something
and it could be anything whatever task or whatever type of action you want to be able to perform if
you possess the means of skill to do something you have the ability to do it and then our notion of
disability has also changed a lot over years so this is a this is kind of the working definition from the world health
organization that they put on 2001 which essentially shows that you know disability is complex it's
actually not just something that's static and it's not something that's within a person it's actually something that has to do
with different type of contextual and environmental factors that actually impact what makes something
accessible and what is disabling to somebody in any given scenario um so this is important because we can
look at ability-based design and it's asking us to ask these questions like well what context is someone using this device or
this system what what is the environment like at this time when they're doing these things and if we can understand
something around these different variables we can make our systems more accessible as a result um
and i wanted to end with this last thing here about ability-based design which i think is really useful and it's called the positive affirmation of ability so
what they're saying here is that everyone has abilities some people more than others and what's really
important is that we need to design for people with abilities of all types so that's kind of like this main takeaway is you know once again
foreground ability make ability the thing that you're trying to design for
so that's kind of my spiel on how i think about accessibility and accessibility research and so now i kind of want to just talk
about like my general research approach um so typically what i do is i like to
um evaluate what we call these ability assumptions so an ability assumption so if you think
about this all human operated technologies contain embedded ability assumptions rather explicit or implicit so
that's every technology not just computer technologies but you know whatever anything that's been
made by humans anything that's been designed by humans it's going to have these assumptions embedded in them that are going to dictate
how people are expected to use them or how people can use them and it's really important that
when we think about technologies and either when we're designing new technologies or trying to understand how to make past technologies more
accessible is we really need to understand at the core of them what are the ability assumptions what are we
and what are we anticipating people can do or what are we expecting people to be able to do when they interact with these
technologies and we need to understand how those expectations and how all those assumptions are actually
creating systems and applications that are actually um preventing people from being able to use
it and it can actually be quite exclusionary so for my dissertation work i looked at
the ability assumptions and kind of embedded inside the kind of what you think of as just like a touchscreen device
so there are some things that we just kind of take for granted right the affordances of a touchscreen and how they and what they allow us to do so
we assume that we can do things just like you know you could tap with a single finger if you want to select a target you can
like both lift and land inside of it you could perform both you know two-handed i mean
two-finger and single-finger gestures like a swipe or pinch to zoom or things like that uh but what i found in my research is
that people are actually use all different types of ways to interact with the touch screen so this is a research study that we did
back in 2015 because it was published in 2016 but we essentially created this test bed and
we just asked people that hey touch this crosshair that's placed on the screen but touch in whichever way is most comfortable and natural to you
like and this is all with people with limited mobility primarily people's cerebral palsy we did
the study at a place in seattle called prevail which used to be united cerebral palsy center
and essentially what we find is you know like hey people might touch the screen with multiple fingers kind of like the way this participant is showing now
so they're kind of hitting the crosshair on the screen kind of using their thumb as kind of like the primary pointing
implement but still interacting with the screen with various fingers which in a normal case
would actually be really inaccurate for the system because it's not expecting all of those touch input points um and you can also see people do
different types of like dragging their hands and different types of behaviors right so this is a person who's kind of
using the screen for stability and it's kind of dragging her hand towards her crosshair it's kind of doing
a little dwell and then kind of moving their hand back um so essentially this project was part
of a well this one piece of the project was part of a bigger research goal which was like to
understand how can we model touch behavior so if we can understand the touch behaviors that people use when they're interacting with
touchscreen devices then we can train touch screen systems to respond more accurately to people's
innate touch behaviors and we can make these systems more accessible as a result but part of it comes from understanding
these ability assumptions right and not just going in and expecting people to interact with the system the way you
want them to what the way you expect them to people are going to do things that work for them and we need to make those things work for
them in turn so kind of my general research approach here
when i approach a new problem is i really try to identify and question what these ability assumptions are so
whatever technology i'm working on either if i'm developing a new technology or trying to retrofit a past technology
this is a really important question to look at is what are the ability assumptions and then i consider myself like an input
and interaction person i like i get really excited about thinking about ways to create new input schemes
and interaction methods to allow people to interact with computing devices in ways that maybe they weren't able to before so
based off this notion of understanding what these assumptions are and understanding what people could do then i can take that knowledge and
actually start to create interaction techniques that are actually more accessible to people and then the last part is actually you
know evaluating the things we build with target users which is like i don't probably don't have to say it to this group you know
very important you know if you actually want to create technologies that work with people with cerebral palsy or muscular dystrophy or
parkinson's it's really important to actually then go out and not only do the co-design with them but then actually do
the evaluation so that you can actually get an accurate representation of how well your system works or your
interaction techniques work in this case okay so that was kind of like the
background portion of the talk so a little bit about how i think about accessibility a little bit about my past research and
how things are going so what i'm going to talk about now is some of the research that my group has been doing so me primarily for some
of these projects but my group in general what we've been doing around trying to make virtual reality more accessible like i mentioned a couple
months ago it's been really difficult to try to do this work the way we want to given the restrictions of copen19 and
all of that entails um you know i think when you work with people with disabilities it's really important to do these co-design
kind of activities and actually be able to observe people interact with devices actually be able to be there and collect
data in a much much more rich kind of way so what i'm going to talk about now is
some of the kind of initial stuff that we've been doing kind of you know given all of the limitations that we have
around covet but my real hope from this conversation is that some of the problems that i might
identify you might be really interested in and it might make you actually think about virtual reality or more broadly how
spatial computing and things like that might be inaccessible to people with disabilities it might motivate you or you know
encourage you all to think about you know doing some research in this space so that's kind of the hope of i'm
going to have from doing this part of the talk so just really brief kind of like
background of virtual reality so um people most people following this call are probably familiar with vr
you know it's an immersive technology that allows people to to be embodied in different experiences
and to you know navigate and explore different type of virtual environments and offers a lot of benefits over
traditional kind of 2d computing devices like you know desktop or mobile systems really this level of immersion and
presence and embodiment is really something that is really hard to to replicate um in a traditional
traditional computing sense so you know virtual reality you know primarily used for gaming i think that's kind of like the biggest
market for it right now but you could also use it for things like medical training architectural walkthroughs so the point
i wanted to make here is that you know virtual reality just isn't well probably won't be just a technology
that's just used for gaming and entertainment it's not too hard to believe that actually you know people for their
jobs and their professions and educational scenarios are going to be using virtual reality for a
lot of different types of applications and use cases so it's really important to think about how we can make these things accessible
because if the devices and applications aren't accessible then those experiences as a result won't be accessible either
um so this has been an explosion kind of like really like in the last five or six years um in a number of kind
of commercial vr systems that are available so yeah and i have the whole like oculus family of devices htc
now kind of has the vibe and the cosmos and a couple of devices and then windows also has a mixed reality
platform that um companies like acer and i think um
like hp also kind of have their own type of vr headsets that's running the windows mixed reality platform
so this is an interesting point to really get into this space because vr isn't in
its emphasis anymore people have been doing vr research for decades but it also hasn't reached this kind of
like mass production or mass adoption yet so there's still tons of
people who haven't had the opportunity to try vr vr systems are still going to be changing in form factors and sizes and
things like that but it's really really an opportunity to think about accessibility before this perhaps potential mass
adoption occurs um so yeah so like what i'll be talking about so there's this notion that you
know vr is really great for a lot of things but virtual reality really does has an accessibility problem so this is a
screen grab of a little clip that i have from a scientific american article article in which it says virtual reality has
been touted as an empathy machine that lets users see what it's like to have a disability but people with disabilities often can
use it so it's this notion here that um virtual reality
can have potential for example you know for empathy training and things like that but people with disabilities themselves
don't often can't have access to these systems so a paper that i wrote along with
by cobra along with a bunch of other people at microsoft research we wrote this paper at the ismart
conference in 2019 called accessible by design and opportunity for virtual reality and what we tried to do is actually try
to lay out the case for well when we're thinking about virtual reality systems and how we want to make them accessible what are really some of
the things that we should be focusing on so where should our priorities be and how should we think about what we're
doing in this space to make these things more accessible so we identified kind of five key areas
of focus content accessibility interaction accessibility device accessibility
inclusive representations and application diversity so i'm gonna touch on most of these
in this talk here but for this first part i'm actually going to just focus on the interaction accessibility and the
device accessibility as it relates primarily to people with limited mobility
so first is device accessibility so one of the reasons why vr is so
inaccessible is because the devices that we have to use to implement to interact with underlining
experiences and applications like i mentioned before make a lot of assumptions about users
and their abilities and this gonna this facilitates the needs for more customizable hardware but
also more just accessible hardware in terms of looking at things that people can do already so like what
devices do people already use and then how can we integrate that with more accessible technologies
so when we think about vr accessibility there's this or when we think about vr in general there's this really
er strong urge to actually want to make things kind of like as realistic as possible to
really embed the user inside the virtual environment and have really tight mappings between what the user can do
and what the system does in turn inside the virtual reality system but if the devices that we use to
actually be able to create this level of immersion aren't accessible to people then the whole system kind of breaks
down so we need to think about ways to actually make the devices accessible to people because if they're not they won't be able to engage in the systems in the
first place um so there's been some work that's looked at this um for people who are blind for example so
this is a project called the cane troller that was done at microsoft research
a few years ago that was led by an intern um yuang who's now a professor at
university of wisconsin essentially we're looking at well how can you make interactions inside vr more
accessible to people who are blind well you can actually create custom hardware to allow people to have these kind of tactile sensations or
feelings when they're actually interacting inside of a virtual world so this is a great project that um alexa
actually came the couple years ago and actually um worked on kind of like a follow-up to this
project and actually made some really great improvements so this is like one really interesting and really useful way of thinking about
device accessibility it's like well how can we create new things that allow people to have new experiences
um i when i joined a team i you know like i mentioned before for my dissertation research i was really
looking at things from standpoint of limited mobility so when we came into this i was really looking
at these type of questions well you know what accessibility varies to people with limited mobility and counter reusing vr systems so like just
commercial vr systems what barriers might they encounter and then for people who have used vr
systems what strategies have they employed to try to overcome some of these accessibility barriers
so to help us answer these questions we ran this interview study we had 16 participants with limited mobility we
had a mix of in-person and remote interviews and we had a couple of people with prior
vr experience the vr experience was nice to have but we didn't want to over index on that because it's just
really hard to find people um who have either used vr and have found it accessible to them
um so for the people who are actually in person that came in and did the study and the people didn't have and they
didn't have prior vr experience we actually gave it an opportunity to try out these three different vr apps
so one is like all space vr it's like a social vr environment oculus first contact you could think of
as like a tutorial type of thing to teaching you how to use hand tracked controllers and things and then google earth vr which we just
thought could be an interesting application for people to play around with to get a sense of how they like the
vr experience so from this paper that we published at assets um just last year
um it was the conference was in october we essentially identified what we call these like seven vr
accessibility barriers so things like setting up a vr system putting on it taking off at hmd
adjusting the hmd head strap cord management manipulating dual motion controllers inaccessible buttons and
maintaining view of the controllers were things that we identified as just hey if somebody wants to be able to interact with a vr system
just kind of like once they open the box here are some of the issues that they're going to have to deal with for trying to think about somebody's
kind of concerns so i'm going to talk not about all of these i just kind of want to highlight a couple and some of these you might look at it
might be like okay yeah that makes sense but why is that a concern or why is that like a hci problem so
so for example we could just look at things like you know adjusting the hmd head strap or and you can kind of tie this in more
broadly with putting on and taking off the hmd so in terms of like design and how we
think about these things there's just some like functional design thing so for example this um p1 said uh one thing i noticed
is that the back strapping is stick so it touches like my headrest so a headrest that might be included on
a wheelchair or power wheelchair so that makes it difficult for this person to move their head for example so
just the way that this thing is designed and it wasn't necessarily thought about how you would design it so that it would
work well for someone who seated in the wheelchair can actually make it in their case difficult for them to move their head
and have these other interactions but it also kind of speaks to this broader question that you're going to have of
well like hey how do we create more accessible type of like wearable technologies more broadly for
people with physical disabilities so it's not just a question of how can i have something that
might interfere with my headset there are people who might have difficulty raising their arms above their chest for
example or lifting their arms head lifting their hands above their head so if we had these technologies that
presume a certain level of control and a certain level of autonomy how does that break down then if people
then have to understand how people can't use this in a way that they may have wanted to because the
technology just wasn't designed in a way that makes it accessible to them like we need to think more broadly around the
design of these technologies not just for hmds but other types of wearable technologies
that might be exclusion that might be excluding people with physical disabilities from taking part um
so there's another one that is more relevant to some of the research i'm going to talk about after this is so let's thought about
manipulating dual motion controller so unlike in a traditional desktop computing sense where it's kind of like
you know you kind of have one pointing implement as the main focus of control so you either have like a mouse or a trackball
or you're using your finger on a touchscreen um in a vr environment you could have two controllers and use both
hands to do different things at different times but that could also be challenging for people with limited mobility um so one of these
quotes here from participant14 said i can only use one hand for the controller so
i so i use my right hand to control one of the sticks and i think having the one-handed barrier is quite common for people who have strokes um
and then another participant p2 here that says like you know i just wouldn't use it too much or requires coordination
it could be really frustrating and kind of in tandem with this is this
notion that hey these um these controllers themselves aren't just used for like their motion tracking
capabilities uh people also have to interact with the individual buttons and things on them to actually you know
perform these interactions so we have one participant here p6 and this is kind of represented in
the image here it's saying it's like yeah i think walking was pushing down so this is walking in a virtual environment
um so you push one of the joysticks down and then to do that i had to use two hands and leave the other controller to
do it as soon as i heard that you have to push it down i was like yep nope that's not happening and that's primarily because people
might have low strength for example in their hands or low dexterity so if you're expecting people to be able to
hold and manipulate multiple buttons at the same time while still holding this controller like participant six said that might not
be possible for them they might actually have to like stop what they're doing put another controller down and then use both hands to just
press down the joystick right um so when we ask people kind of like well
what are these what would be some things that you might want to see like what will make these experiences more accessible
to you uh so some people mention things like well just like alternative input controls right so if we can't make this assumption that
everyone who's going to use a virtual reality system is going to have kind of the availability to them of
having two kind of six degrees of freedom tracked controllers that they can use all the time um
how could we do things with people how can we do these interactions with devices that people already use so if
someone uses a quad stick or they use a series of switches or a trackball how what's the possibility for
that and then other ones it's like well how can we use other different types of input modalities so how could we use gaze input or voice input to allow more
accessible vr manipulations but even with gaze and voice we're still not
there yet in terms of understanding how would somebody for example fully control a vr
interface or interact inside of a vr environment using strictly gaze or using strictly
voice is something that we're just not sure yet how to make all of those interactions accessible given the more
limited input modalities that might be available to some people so one possibility and i think that's
really good and i know um patrick carrington was here earlier um in this the quarter um it's to think about
charitable computing so this is this idea that you know shareable computing is really this technology that takes advantage of the
space on or around a wheelchair um as much as you know kind of like leveraging
um on body and warm mobile technology is what wearable computing can do so essentially the idea is well how can
we bring interfaces and enter the devices closer to people so that these then devices can actually then sit
on places that are actually really useful and really beneficial to the person who's using them so one thing that
we were looking at here oh the title of the slide is wrong so forget the accessible bimanual input
part that's coming later um the question that we're actually looking at here is it's um well how do we leverage more traditional
2d input devices things that could fit more comfortably on the form factor of a wheelchair to you
know complete more complex spatial interactions so one thing we looked at what we thought
was actually a good example of this is like virtual hand manipulations so in a vr environment you could use
these touch controllers to perform different type of hand manipulation so you could do things like make a thumbs up or grasp a cube
and use the controller to like throw it or just drop it toss it in different directions so this is something in which there's no
really good design schemes right now to say well how would i use a commodity input device like a joystick and a switch to be able to
perform all these various types of virtual hand manipulations it's something that you know prior work that's looking at
like the design space of input devices for example doesn't really have great answers for in terms of saying hey we have these
complex interactions here's how you might want to map this input device to this complex
interaction so um so for example for this you know we did like a user elicitation study
where we we got 21 participants for limited mobility once again this is happening in covet
time so we weren't able to actually do this in person but we actually did was use the crowd listed platform that abdellah
lee and others created to actually be able to do this like remote use user elicitation study
so we created 16 hand manipulations as reference and what we did was we showed them
each of these kind of like little short videos slightly longer than the videos you see right now the thumbs up and we
just ask people hey how would you use a different types of input devices to be able to
perform this gesture for example so in our study that i'm going to talk about now it's like you know we ask people that's like
hey if you use a touchpad you know it can sense multiple concurrent touch points how
would you use that to perform these type of gestures and some of the things that we found initially up well
to analyze before we get to that to analyze this what we did was we looked at the taxonomy of surface gestures
by robrock at all that looked at okay hey we can analyze different gestures that people make on the touch screen to
understand kind of how people's mental models of these gestures actually work
so some initial findings for example that we have around this that speaks to these notions of mental models for
example are we looked at like discrete hand gestures so we had things in our set of
16 total that were like four discrete hand gestures so this kind of like you know index plus extended finger
closing a fist a thumbs up and what we found was that when we were analyzing people's answers for how they
would perform these gestures 41 which was the most popular um or the most common results were abstract
gestures so abstract gestures are ones in which there's really no mapping between what the person does with the gesture
and how that relates to what the actual referent or the the end result is going to be
so in this case we had people doing a lot of things for example like oh to you know to make the to make a
thumbs up i might tap on the screen three times consecutively or i might do
a tap and then a swirl or something but those gestures don't have really any
indication of what's going on with the actual hand and you compare that to these kind of like grasp and release gestures
um hand manipulations that we looked at 50 57 of those were metaphorical so meaning
that the gesture actually is more tightly bound or tightly related to what the actual hand manipulation is
doing so an example of that for example is we can look at these dichotomous reference so
meaning that there's the same reference but kind of like in reverse in this some in some situation so for example we can
have an action that's just like well how would you grasp an object using this virtual hand and then we can ask well how would you release it
and this speaks to this kind of metaphorical gestures that people were referring to so um so somebody p16 for example would say
so to grasp the cube they said they would squeeze their fingers on the touch pad together to grab the object
and then to release they would kind of just do the opposite or the reverse of the grass gesture which in this case
would just be to extend their fingers um to release so
this is a study that we've actually been really interested in it's something that we think is really useful um here's kind of a diagram that shows
all the 16 different hand manipulations that we implemented and it's useful because what we want to
be able to understand here and kind of different than what you might do in a typical user elicitation
study is where you actually want to come up with some type of consensus and say like hey this is the gesture that would work
really well to perform this action um people with disabilities have so many
different ways that they interact with objects and they do things typically to relate well to their own ability so we're not necessarily looking
for you know consensus and saying like hey this is what people are using but what we're instead looking for is like well what
are these mental models like so you know are there categories of different hand manipulations that might be
harder for people to understand how they would actually implement those uh so for example what we found was that
these translation ones so like move forward move backwards people are able to come up with really
easy gestures for those because they might say just directional swipes for example might be good enough for people to
understand like okay if i want to move something backwards or forwards i might just swipe up and down for that interaction
but like i mentioned before these kind of more um discrete gesture type of things in which
there's not a really great mental models for like how do you do a thumbs up on a touchpad um we might have to think about ways
that uh create more accessible mappings for those different types of interactions so this is like one example of ways that
we need to think about how commodity input devices can be used in a way to create much more complex expressive
interactions when we actually get to vr and different type of augmented reality
interfaces um so some of the takeaways that we had from not just the study
that i just mentioned but the the assets paper uh this actually comes from the assets paper so
just a couple of things in terms of design so one thing that's really important is this notion like designing for interdependence so
interdependence is kind of a design framework in which you don't think about how a person would do something independently
you actually try to understand and acknowledge that people with disabilities often work with
other people a lot of the times to do different things so people might work with caregivers and friends and families
um for lots of different interactions and what we heard from our participants was that
hey when thinking about how to create more accessible vr systems just don't think about the one user to one person
think about the ecosystem that that person is in how could you help or how could you involve
caregivers and family members in the process to make these devices and systems more accessible to them like how
people work together to do certain things um design for customization really comes to this question of saying
you know we really need input controls and interaction methods that people can really take advantage of create more bespoke solutions but at the
development level we really need to think about how to enable that level of flexibility and control
um design for accessibility so this is really just meaning more towards like ability right so if you're thinking
about different ways that people might use a system you really want to put the ability part first and
really put that in the foreground and then the last one is this that design for diversity
one of the things that came up in our interviews with participants was that people felt that there was this expectation that you know if something
was un was inaccessible to them that that was kind of like okay like it was just like well this wasn't made for you
you know like why would you want to be a part of this experience this is an experience for people who can walk or experience for people
who can throw and if you can't walk or throw then you should want to be able to engage in these experiences
what we found is that like you know people want to interact with vr systems in all types of ways so don't kind of make the assumption that
like hey what matters the most is just immersion or what matters the most is embodiment in these certain situations
really consider what people want and how they're going to interact in these different type of situations
so the next thing i want to talk about is this notion of interaction accessibility so
like i mentioned and when we talked about device accessibility vr much more than these traditional
systems think about physical input and output and it's really bad in terms of
understanding how people with limited mobility can translate what their physical actions are into the actions
that the system can interpret and use in a in a way to make their interactions
easier and more enjoyable to use so when we make these vr inputs and outputs
like we increase the fidelity of them essentially what we're doing is that we're importing a lot of the things that are inaccessible
inaccessible about the physical world and we're importing them into the virtual world so if there is an
action or something that was hard for you to do in the virtual world but in the real world but now the virtual
world expects you to perform that action the same exact way we're just now making the virtual world just as inaccessible
as the as the real world um so we need to really think about these inaccessible methods and user
interfaces that can work well for these more accessible devices that we also create
so another example of this for people who are blind or low vision is this system called seeing vr
which is essentially this collection of enhancements that will allow people to to allow
people with limited vision to be able to have more accessible interactions in vr
by doing things like having edge enhancement having magnification lenses things like that and again where i'm
really looking forward is how does this work for people of limited mobility so um i was really interested in this
question of accessible bimanual input and one of the participants actually has this quote so
um and talking about using two hands to perform actions in vr they said i'm not sure that that would be possible for me to do them
simultaneously if i had to do i could do it one-handed but if i had to do both hands at the
same time that's not going to work so you might have people for example who are amputees that might have access to
one arm or one hand you might have people who might have more strength or more movement and one
hemisphere of their body compared to the other so people might prefer to just use a single controller to be able to do these
input manipulations but then the question becomes well how do we do these kind of like complex bi-manual input actions if i
just have a single input modality um so this is the question we ask so i
have the great intern ramona yamagami who's a uh phd cam at university washington who
was intern with me last summer and we kind of explored some of these areas so once again as you know how can we allow
people to control bimanual interfaces with unimanual input so what we did is we started off with this kind of popular framework the
guillard framework for this asymmetric division of labor so this really tells us is that like hey we can really think about it as like
there's only really a few types of bimanual interactions so there's symmetric end phase in which
both hands do the same role at the same time so you could think of that as like um jumper roping both
hands are kind of like working in tandem on the deduction action um symmetric out of phase is that both
hands do the same action but at different times so if you're thinking about something like climbing a rope or a ladder one hand
might go and then the other hand might go so both hands are doing the same action just at different times
asymmetric coordinated is when both hands are working together on like a single object so you could
think of that as something like you know you're cutting an apple one hand holds the apple while the other hand is kind
of actually doing the slicing and then you can think of asymmetric uncoordinated as two hands are just
doing two different things and they're not coordinated with each other so that could be like in a gaming scenario it could be
you know you hold a shield with your left hand and you hold a sword when your right hand and in theory you know you could
bash in one direction with the shield while swiping with the sword so there's really no way to identify
kind of what the two things are doing um so if you're really thinking about like well how can we create interaction
techniques for this space well you can maybe think about it along the spectrum of like well how much autonomy do you want the user to have right
so you can really think it's like okay if i have a spectrum between less autonomy to more autonomy what can i do with that
so with less autonomy in terms of the user actually having some input and what's going to happen
maybe you say hey if the user encounters a bi-manual task we just automatically perform a task for
them or we give them the option to automatically perform the task um so that could be something like you know hey you encounter a ladder
you can just automatically climb the ladder we're not going to have you do the two-handed interaction piece uh similarly if you want something
that's more in the middle you can maybe do something where you actually infer the output of the two hands given input from the
one hand so if i know what one hand with one hand is doing could i then infer what the other hand should be
doing based off the input that i'm getting from the one hand and then if you really want to give people a lot of autonomy maybe you could
do something like use an alternative input method so maybe you can use the headset or that eye gaze as something to compensate for not
having the other hand uh so what you could do then is you know whatever designs or
interaction techniques you come up with on the spectrum from less to more autonomy then you can kind of overlay those with
you know what's happening with these different type of interaction methods so in this case i'm
going to go through an example of saying like okay well if i have automatic inferring or alternative what does that look like for
symmetric autophase interactions um so for example if i wanted to infer the location of a virtual hand in this
symmetric out-of-phase thing perhaps what i'll do is i'll create a system in which the virtual hand
kind of always just mimics the direction speed and distance of what the real hand is doing so if the
real hand performs some movement up to climb the ladder and win a certain distance i'll just have the virtual hand
mimic that interaction by going the same distance and speed and everything else and then i could just have a snap to
kind of like whatever the coast closest like interactable object is um so the benefits of that is like you know could be less fatigue um
it could be you could perform more movement simultaneously but once again the user has less control and then

let's say i want to use like the hmo headset to identify the location of the

you could have issues with overloading and it could be not as accessible as some you to some users so an example of that could be this

your avatar has varying diff um very different abilities than what you possess

an avatar that does walk and has use of both hands and things like that is that actually an immersive experience

so vr provides these opportunities to kind of do different types of application types so you could do things like virtual

for people with disabilities i mean when you're designing this like think about ability when you're designing these interactive
